original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita.

original: śrībhagavān uvāca
analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: ūrdhvamūlam adhaḥśākham aśvatthaṃ prāhur avyayam /
analyzed: ūrdhva mūlam adhas śākham aśvattham prāhuḥ avyayam
translated: They call the undecaying fig tree to have its root above and branches below.

original: chandāṃsi yasya parṇāni yas taṃ veda sa vedavit ////
analyzed: chandāṃsi yasya parṇāni yaḥ tam veda sa veda vid
translated: He who knows it, whose leaves are the Vedas, is the knower of the Vedas.

original: śrīdharaḥ /
translated: Sri Sridhara.

original: vairāgyeṇa vinā jñānaṃ na ca bhaktir ataḥ sphuṭam /
analyzed: vairāgyeṇa vinā jñānam na ca bhaktiḥ atas sphuṭam
translated: Knowledge without detachment, and devotion without that, are not clear.

original: vairāgyopaskṛtaṃ jñānam īśaḥ pañcadaśe 'diśat //
analyzed: vairāgya upaskṛtam jñānam īśaḥ pañcadaśe diśat
translated: The Lord has instructed knowledge, which is served by detachment, in the fifteenth chapter.

original: pūrvādhyānte māṃ ca yo 'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate Gītā / ity ādinā parameśvaram ekāntabhaktyā bhajatas tatprasādalabdhajñānena
analyzed: pūrva adhyā ante mām ca yaḥ vyabhicāreṇa bhakti yogena sevate gītāḥ iti ādinā parameśvaram ekānta bhaktyā bhajataḥ tad prasāda labdha jñānena
translated: At the end of the previous chapter, it was said that one who serves Me with unwavering devotion of yoga, by worshipping the Supreme Lord with single-pointed devotion,

original: brahmabhāvo bhavatīty uktam /
analyzed: brahma bhāvaḥ bhavati iti uktam
translated: attains identity with Brahman through knowledge obtained by His grace.

original: na caikāntabhaktiḥ jñānaṃ cāviraktasya sambhavatīti vairāgyapūrvakaṃ jñānam upadeṣṭukāmaḥ
analyzed: na ca ekānta bhaktiḥ jñānam ca aviraktasya sambhavati iti vairāgya pūrvakam jñānam upadeṣṭu kāmaḥ
translated: And single-pointed devotion and knowledge are not possible for one who is not detached. Therefore, desiring to teach knowledge preceded by detachment,

original: prathamaṃ tāvat sārdhaślokābhyāṃ saṃsārasvarūpaṃ vṛkṣarūpakālaṅkāreṇa varṇayan
analyzed: prathamam tāvat sārdha ślokābhyām saṃsāra svarūpam vṛkṣa rūpaka alaṅkāreṇa varṇayan
translated: first, in two and a half verses, describing the nature of worldly existence with the figure of speech of a tree,

original: bhagavān uvāca ūrdhvamūlam iti /
analyzed: bhagavān uvāca ūrdhva mūlam iti
translated: the Blessed Lord said: Having its root above and branches below.

original: ūrdhvam uttamaḥ kṣarākṣarābhyām utkṛṣṭaḥ puruṣottamo mūlaṃ yasya tam /
analyzed: ūrdhvam uttamaḥ kṣara akṣarābhyām utkṛṣṭaḥ puruṣottamaḥ mūlam yasya tam
translated: That which has the Supreme Person, who is superior to the perishable and the imperishable, as its root, is called so.

original: adha iti tato 'rvācīnāṃ kāryopādhayo hiraṇyagarbhādayo gṛhyante /
analyzed: adhas iti tatas rvācīnām kārya upādhayaḥ hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ gṛhyante
translated: The word 'adha' (below) refers to the effects like Hiranyagarbha and others that are subsequent to that.

original: te tu śākhā iva śākhā yasya tam /
analyzed: te tu śākhā iva śākhā yasya tam
translated: They are like branches, and He is the one who has them.

original: vinaśvaratvena śvaḥ prabhātaparyantam api na sthāsyatīti viśvāsānarhatvād aśvatthaṃ prāhuḥ /
analyzed: vinaśvara tvena śvas prabhāta paryantam api na sthāsyati iti viśvāsa anarha tvāt aśvattham prāhuḥ
translated: They call it the 'ashvattha' tree, because it is perishable and not worthy of confidence that it will last even till tomorrow morning.

original: pravāharūpeṇāvicchedād avyayaṃ ca prāhuḥ /🔽ūrdhvamūlo 'vākśākha eṣo
analyzed: pravāha rūpeṇa a vicchedāt avyayam ca prāhuḥ  ūrdhva mūlaḥ vāc śākhaḥ eṣaḥ
translated: They also call it 'avyama' (imperishable) because it continues without interruption.🔽This ashvattha tree has its root above and branches below.

original: 'śvatthaḥ sanātana KaṭhU / / ity ādyāḥ śrutayaḥ /
analyzed: śvatthaḥ sanātana kaṭhu iti ādyāḥ śrutayaḥ
translated: It is eternal. These are the Vedic statements.

original: chandāṃsi vedā yasya parṇāni dharmādharmapratipādanadvāreṇa cchāyāsthānīyaiḥ karmaphalaiḥ saṃsāravṛkṣasya sarvajīvāśrayaṇīyatvapratipādanāt
analyzed: chandāṃsi vedāḥ yasya parṇāni dharma adharma pratipādana dvāreṇa chāyā sthānīyaiḥ karma phalaiḥ saṃsāra vṛkṣasya sarva jīva āśrayaṇīya tva pratipādanāt
translated: The Vedas are its leaves, because it establishes that the tree of worldly existence is the support of all living beings through the fruits of actions that are like shadows by means of teaching dharma and adharma.

original: parṇasthānīyā vedāḥ /
analyzed: parṇa sthānīyāḥ vedāḥ
translated: The Vedas are like leaves.

original: yas tam evambhūtam aśvatthaṃ veda sa eva vedārthavit /
analyzed: yaḥ tam evambhūtam aśvattham veda saḥ eva veda artha vid
translated: One who knows this ashvattha tree in this way is indeed a knower of the meaning of the Vedas.

original: saṃsāraprapañcavṛkṣasya mūlam īśvaraḥ /
analyzed: saṃsāra prapañca vṛkṣasya mūlam īśvaraḥ
translated: The root of the tree of worldly existence is God.

original: brahmādayas tadaṃśāḥ śākhāsthānīyāḥ /
analyzed: brahma ādayaḥ tad aṃśāḥ śākhā sthānīyāḥ
translated: Brahma and others are like its branches.

original: sa ca saṃsāravṛkso vinaśvaraḥ /
analyzed: sa ca saṃsāra vṛksaḥ vinaśvaraḥ
translated: And that tree of worldly existence is perishable.

original: pravāharūpeṇa nityaś ca /
analyzed: pravāha rūpeṇa nityaḥ ca
translated: But it is also eternal in the form of a continuous flow.

original: vedoktaiḥ karmabhiḥ sevyatām āpāditaś ca ity etāvān eva hi vedārthaḥ /
analyzed: veda uktaiḥ karmabhiḥ sevyatām āpāditaḥ ca iti etāvān eva hi veda arthaḥ
translated: And it is by the rites enjoined in the Vedas that it is attained. This is the whole purport of the Vedas.

original: ata evaṃ vidvān vedavid iti stūyate ////
analyzed: atas evam vidvān veda vid iti stūyate
translated: Therefore, one who knows this is praised as a knower of the Vedas.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: pūrvādhyāye bhagavtā saṃsārabandhahetūn guṇān vyākhyāya teṣām atyayena brahmabhāvo mokṣo madbhajanena labhyata ity uktam
analyzed: pūrva adhyāye bhagavtā saṃsāra bandha hetūn guṇān vyākhyāya teṣām atyayena brahma bhāvaḥ mokṣaḥ mad bhajanena labhyate iti uktam
translated: In the previous chapter, the Lord, having explained the qualities that are the causes of the bondage of worldly existence, said that liberation, which is the state of Brahman, is attained by devotion to Him,

original: māṃ ca yo 'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate /
analyzed: mām ca yaḥ vyabhicāreṇa bhakti yogena sevate
translated: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotion to God,

original: sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahmabhūyāya kalpate // Gītā / iti /
analyzed: sa guṇān samatītya etān brahma bhūyāya kalpate gītāḥ iti
translated: he, having transcended these qualities, becomes fit for the state of Brahman. (14.26) Gītā.

original: tatra manuṣyasya tava bhaktiyogena kathaṃ brahmabhāva ity āśaṅkāyāṃ svasya brahmarūpatājñāpanāya sūtrabhūto 'yaṃ śloko bhagavatoktaḥ
analyzed: tatra manuṣyasya tava bhakti yogena katham brahma bhāvaḥ iti āśaṅkāyām svasya brahma rūpa tā jñāpanāya sūtra bhūtaḥ yam ślokaḥ bhagavatā uktaḥ
translated: There, when there is doubt as to how one can attain the state of Brahman by devotion to you, the human Lord, this verse, which is like a sūtra, was spoken by the Lord to indicate His own nature as Brahman,

original: brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāham amṛtasyāvyayasya ca /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ hi pratiṣṭhā aham amṛtasya avyayasya ca
translated: For I am the support of Brahman, of immortality, of the imperishable,

original: śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca //Gītā / iti /
analyzed: śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasya aikāntikasya ca gītā iti
translated: of eternal Dharma, and of absolute bliss. (15.17) Gītā.

original: asya sūtrasya vṛttisthānīyo 'yaṃ pañcadaśo 'dhyāya ārabhyate /
analyzed: asya sūtrasya vṛtti sthānīyaḥ yam pañcadaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ ārabhyate
translated: This fifteenth chapter begins as a commentary on this sūtra.

original: bhagavataḥ śrīkṛṣṇasya hi tattvaṃ jñātvā tatpremabhajanena guṇātītaḥ san brahmabhāvaṃ katham āpnuyāl loka iti /
analyzed: bhagavataḥ śrī kṛṣṇasya hi tattvam jñātvā tad prema bhajanena guṇa atītaḥ san brahma bhāvam katham āpnuyāt loke iti
translated: The question is: How can a person attain the state of Brahman by knowing the truth of the Lord Sri Krishna and by His devotional service, becoming transcendental to the modes of material nature?

original: tatra brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāham ity ādi bhagavadvacanam ākarṇya mama tulyo manuṣyo
analyzed: tatra brahmaṇaḥ hi pratiṣṭhā aham iti ādi bhagavat vacanam ākarṇya mama tulyaḥ manuṣyaḥ
translated: There, having heard the words of the Lord such as I am the resting place of Brahman etc., Arjuna, thinking How can a human being like me

original: 'yaṃ katham evaṃ vadatīti vismayāviṣṭam apratibhayā lajjayā ca kiṃcid api praṣṭum
analyzed: yam katham evam vadati iti vismaya āviṣṭam apratibhayā lajjayā ca kiṃcid api praṣṭum
translated: speak like this?, filled with wonder, lack of confidence, and shame, unable to ask anything at all,

original: aśaknuvan tam arjunam ālakṣya kṛpayā svasvarūpaṃ vivakṣuḥ śrībhagavān uvāca ūrdhveti /
analyzed: aśaknuvan tam arjunam ālakṣya kṛpayā sva svarūpam vivakṣuḥ śrī bhagavān uvāca ūrdhva iti
translated: seeing that Arjuna was like that, the Lord Sri Krishna, out of compassion, desiring to speak of His own nature, said Urdhvam etc.

original: tatra viraktasyaiva saṃsārād bhagavattattvajñāne 'dhikāro nānyatheti pūrvādhyāyoktaṃ🔽parameśvarādhīnaprakṛtipuruṣasaṃyogakāryaṃ saṃsāraṃ vṛkṣarūpakalpanayā varṇayati🔽vairāgyāya prastutaguṇātītatvopāyatvāt tasya /
analyzed: tatra viraktasya eva saṃsārāt bhagavat tattva jñāne dhikāraḥ na anyathā iti pūrva adhyāya uktam  parameśvara adhīna prakṛti puruṣa saṃyoga kāryam saṃsāram vṛkṣa rūpa kalpanayā varṇayati  vairāgyāya prastuta guṇa atīta tva upāya tvāt tasya
translated: There, only one who is detached from the world is qualified to know the truth of the Lord, not otherwise. This was stated in the previous chapter.🔽The world, which is the result of the union of Prakriti and Purusha under the control of the Supreme Lord, is described by the metaphor of a tree,🔽for the sake of detachment, because it is the means to attain the state of being transcendental to the modes of material nature, which is the subject matter at hand.

original: ūrdhvam utkṛṣṭaṃ mūlaṃ kāraṇaṃ svaprakāśaparamānandarūpatvena nityatvena ca brahma /
analyzed: ūrdhvam utkṛṣṭam mūlam kāraṇam sva prakāśa paramānanda rūpa tvena nitya tvena ca brahma
translated: The root is above, i.e. the best cause, which is Brahman, in the form of self-luminous supreme bliss and eternity.

original: atahvordhvaṃ sarvasaṃsārabādhe 'py abādhitaṃ sarvasaṃsārabhramādhiṣṭhānaṃ brahma tad eva māyayā mūlam asyety ūrdhvamūlam /
analyzed: a tahva ūrdhvam sarva saṃsāra bādhe pi a bādhitam sarva saṃsāra bhrama adhiṣṭhānam brahma tat eva māyayā mūlam asya iti ūrdhva mūlam
translated: Above that, Brahman, which is not affected even by all the troubles of the world, and which is the basis of all the illusions of the world, is itself the root of this (world) by Maya. Thus it has roots above.

original: adha ity arvācīnāḥ kāryopādhayo hiraṇyagrabhādyā gṛhyante /
analyzed: adhas iti arvācīnāḥ kārya upādhayaḥ hiraṇyagrabha ādyāḥ gṛhyante
translated: Below refers to the lower, created limiting adjuncts beginning with Hiranyagarbha, which are grasped.

original: te nānādikprasṛtatvāc chākhā iva śākhā asyety adhaḥśākham /
analyzed: te nānā diś prasṛta tvāt śākhāḥ iva śākhāḥ asya iti adhaḥśākham
translated: They are like branches of this (tree) because they extend in various directions. Thus it has branches below.

original: āśuvināśitvena na śvo 'pi sthāteti viśvāsānarham aśvattham māyāmayaṃ saṃsāravṛkṣam avyayam anādyanantadehādisantānāśrayam ātmajñānam
analyzed: āśu vināśi tvena na śvas pi sthātā iti viśvāsa anarham aśvattham māyā mayam saṃsāra vṛkṣam avyayam anādi ananta deha ādi santāna āśrayam ātma jñānam
translated: The imperishable, undecaying Brahman, which is the support of the beginningless and endless series of bodies etc., is the knowledge of the Self.

original: anantam avyayam āhuḥ śrutayaḥ smṛtayaś ca /
analyzed: anantam avyayam āhuḥ śrutayaḥ smṛtayaḥ ca
translated: The Vedas and the Smritis declare it to be endless and imperishable.

original: śrutayas tāvat ūrdhvamūlo 'vākśākha eṣo 'śvatthaḥ sanātanaḥ KaṭhU / / ity ādyaḥ kaṭhavallīṣu paṭhitāḥ /
analyzed: śrutayaḥ tāvat ūrdhva mūlaḥ vāc śākhaḥ iti ādyaḥ kaṭhavallīṣu paṭhitāḥ
translated: The Vedas, for instance, declare in the Katha Upanishad: This eternal Asvattha tree has its roots above and branches below.

original: arvāñco nikṛṣṭāḥ kāryopādhayo mahadahaṅkāratanmātrādayo vā śākhā asyety arvākśākha ity adhaḥśākhapadasamānārthaḥ /
analyzed: arvāñcaḥ nikṛṣṭāḥ kārya upādhayaḥ mahat ahaṅkāra tanmātra ādayaḥ vā śākhāḥ asya iti arvāc śākhaḥ iti adhas śākhā pada samāna arthaḥ
translated: The lower, inferior created limiting adjuncts, or the Mahat, Ahamkara, Tanmatras etc., are its branches. Thus it has branches below, which has the same meaning as the word 'branches below'.

original: sanātana tiy avyayapadasamānārtham /
analyzed: sanātana tiy avyaya pada samāna artham
translated: 'Eternal' has the same meaning as 'imperishable'.

original: smṛtayaś ca
analyzed: smṛtayaḥ ca
translated: And the Smritis also declare:🔽The Self is to be known by the Vedas, by austerities, by gifts, by meditation, by renunciation, by knowledge, by truth, by contentment, by harmlessness, by celibacy.

original: avyaktamūlaprabhavas tasyaivānugrahotthitaḥ /
analyzed: avyakta mūla prabhavaḥ tasya eva anugraha utthitaḥ
translated: Having the unmanifest as its root and origin, arisen from the grace of that [unmanifest],

original: buddhiskandhamayaś caiva indriyāntarakoṭaraḥ //
analyzed: buddhi skandha mayaḥ ca eva indriya antara koṭaraḥ
translated: And having the intellect as its trunk, with the internal organs as its hollows,

original: mahābhūtaviśākhaś ca viṣayaiḥ patravāṃs tathā /
analyzed: mahābhūta viśākhaḥ ca viṣayaiḥ patravān tathā
translated: Having the great elements as its branches, and having the objects as its leaves,

original: dharmādharmasupuṣpaś ca sukhaduḥkhaphalodayaḥ //
analyzed: dharma adharma su puṣpaḥ ca sukha duḥkha phala udayaḥ
translated: Having righteousness and unrighteousness as its flowers, and the arising of the fruits of happiness and sorrow,

original: ājīvyaḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ brahmavṛkṣaḥ sanātanaḥ /
analyzed: ājīvyaḥ sarva bhūtānām brahmavṛkṣaḥ sanātanaḥ
translated: The eternal tree of Brahman, which is the means of sustenance for all beings,

original: etad brahmavanaṃ cāsya brahmācarati sākṣivat //
analyzed: etat brahma vanam ca asya brahmā ācarati sākṣi vat
translated: And this forest of Brahman of his, Brahman himself moves about in it as a witness.

original: etac chittvā ca bhittvā ca jñānena paramāsinā /
analyzed: etat chittvā ca bhittvā ca jñānena parama asinā
translated: Having cut it down and split it with the supreme sword of knowledge,

original: tataś cātmagatiṃ prāpya tasmān nāvartate punaḥ //
analyzed: tatas ca ātma gatim prāpya tasmāt na āvartate punar
translated: And having attained the state of the self, he does not return from that again.

original: Mbh / / ity ādayaḥ /
analyzed: iti ādayaḥ
translated: And so on.

original: avyaktam avyākṛtaṃ māyopādhikaṃ brahma tad eva mūlaṃ kāraṇaṃ tasmāt prabhavo yasya sa tathā /
analyzed: avyaktam avyākṛtam māyā upādhikam brahma tat eva mūlam kāraṇam tasmāt prabhavaḥ yasya sa tathā
translated: The unmanifest is the Brahman with the attribute of Maya. That itself is the root, the cause. From that, it has origin. It is so.

original: tasyaiva mūlasyāvyaktasyānugrahād atidṛḍhatvād utthitaḥ saṃvardhitaḥ /
analyzed: tasya eva mūlasya avyaktasya anugrahāt ati dṛḍha tvāt utthitaḥ saṃvardhitaḥ
translated: Arisen from the grace of that very root, the unmanifest, it has grown, having become very firm.

original: vṛkṣasya hi śākhāḥ skandhād udbhavanti /
analyzed: vṛkṣasya hi śākhāḥ skandhāt udbhavanti
translated: For the branches of a tree grow from the trunk.

original: saṃsārasya ca buddheḥ sakāśān nānāvidhāḥ pariṇāmā bhavanti /
analyzed: saṃsārasya ca buddheḥ sakāśāt nānāvidhāḥ pariṇāmāḥ bhavanti
translated: And the various transformations of the world come from the intellect.

original: tena sādharmyeṇa buddhir eva skandhas tanmayas tatpracuro 'yam /
analyzed: tena sādharmyeṇa buddhiḥ eva skandhaḥ tad mayaḥ tad pracuraḥ yam
translated: In that similarity, the aggregate is indeed the intellect itself, consisting of that, abundant in that.

original: indriyāṇām antarāṇi cchidrāṇy eva koṭarāṇi yasya sa tathā /
analyzed: indriyāṇām antarāṇi chidrāṇi eva koṭarāṇi yasya sa tathā
translated: He who has the cavities, the holes, of the senses, is so.

original: mahānti bhūtāny ākāśādīni pṛthivyantāni vividhāḥ śākhā yasya viśākhaḥ stambho yasyeti vā /
analyzed: mahānti bhūtāni ākāśa ādīni pṛthivī antāni vividhāḥ śākhāḥ yasya viśākhaḥ stambhaḥ yasya iti vā
translated: The great elements beginning with space and ending with earth are the various branches of him, he is Vishakha, or he who has a pillar.

original: ājīvya upajīvyaḥ /
analyzed: ājīvyaḥ upajīvyaḥ
translated: To be lived upon, to be depended upon.

original: brahmaṇā paramātmanādhiṣṭhito vṛkṣo brahmavṛkṣaḥ /
analyzed: brahmaṇā paramātmanā adhiṣṭhitaḥ vṛkṣaḥ brahmavṛkṣaḥ
translated: The tree presided over by Brahman, the supreme Self, is the Brahman tree.

original: ātmajñānaṃ vinā chettum aśakyatayā sanātanaḥ /
analyzed: ātma jñānam vinā chettum aśakya tayā sanātanaḥ
translated: Eternal, because it cannot be cut down without the knowledge of the Self.

original: etad brahmavanam asya brahmaṇo jīvarūpasya bhogyaṃ vananīyaṃ sambhajanīyam iti vanaṃ brahma sākṣivad ācarati
analyzed: etat brahma vanam asya brahmaṇaḥ jīva rūpasya bhogyam vananīyam sambhajanīyam iti vanam brahma sākṣi vat ācarati
translated: This forest of Brahman, which is the object of enjoyment of this Brahman in the form of the individual soul, is to be enjoyed, to be shared, therefore it is a forest. Brahman acts as a witness.

original: na tv etat kṛtena lipyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: na tu etat kṛtena lipyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is not tainted by what is done.

original: etad brahmavanaṃ saṃsāravṛkṣātmakaṃ chittvā ca bhittvā cāhaṃ /🔽brahmāsmīty atidṛḍhajñānakhaḍgena samūlaṃ nikṛtyety arthaḥ ātmarūpāṃ gatiṃ prāpya tasmād ātmarūpān mokṣān nāvartata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: etat brahma vanam saṃsāra vṛkṣa ātmakam chittvā ca bhittvā ca aham  brahmā asmi iti ati dṛḍha jñāna khaḍgena samūlam nikṛtya iti arthaḥ ātma rūpām gatim prāpya tasmāt ātma rūpāt mokṣāt na āvartate iti arthaḥ
translated: Having cut down and split this forest of Brahman, which is in the form of the world tree,

original: spaṣṭam itarat /
analyzed: spaṣṭam itarat
translated: with the sword of the very firm knowledge that I am Brahman, the meaning is that having cut it down with its roots, having attained the state which is in the form of the Self, from that state which is in the form of the Self, i.e. from liberation, he does not return. The rest is clear.

original: atra ca gaṅgātaraṅganudyamānottuṅgatattīratiryaṅnipatitam ardhonmūlitaṃ mārutena mahāntam aśvattham upamānīkṛtya jīvantam iyaṃ rūpakakalpaneti 🔽draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: atra ca gaṅgā taraṅga nudyamāna uttuṅga tad tīra tiryak nipatitam ardha unmūlitam mārutena mahāntam aśvattham upamānīkṛtya jīvantam iyam rūpaka kalpanā iti  draṣṭavyam
translated: And here, taking as the object of comparison a great banyan tree half uprooted by the wind, which falls obliquely on the steep bank raised by the waves of the Ganges, this is to be regarded as a figurative assumption.

original: tena nordhvamūlatvādhaḥśākhatvādyanupapattiḥ /
analyzed: tena na ūrdhva mūla tva adhas śākhā tva ādi anupapattiḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no inconsistency in its having an upward root and downward branches, etc.

original: yasya māyāmayasyāśvatthasya cchandāṃsi cchādanāt tattvavastuprāvaraṇāt saṃsāravṛkṣarakṣaṇād vā karmakāṇḍāni ṛgyajuḥsāmalakṣaṇāni parṇānīva
analyzed: yasya māyā mayasya aśvatthasya chandāṃsi chādanāt tattva vastu prāvaraṇāt saṃsāra vṛkṣa rakṣaṇāt vā karma kāṇḍāni ṛk yajuḥ sāma lakṣaṇāni parṇāni iva
translated: The ritual texts, consisting of the Rig, Yajur, and Sama Vedas, are like the leaves of that illusory banyan tree, because they cover the true reality, or because they protect the tree of worldly existence, by the word chādana (covering).

original: parṇāni /
analyzed: parṇāni
translated: They are leaves.

original: yathā vṛkṣasya parirakṣaṇāthāni parṇāni bhavanti tathā saṃsāravṛkṣasya parirakṣaṇāthāni karmakāṇḍāni dharmādharmaataddhetuphalaprakāśanārthatvāt 🔽teṣām /
analyzed: yathā vṛkṣasya parirakṣaṇa athāni parṇāni bhavanti tathā saṃsāra vṛkṣasya parirakṣaṇa athāni karmakāṇḍāni dharma adharma a tad hetu phala prakāśana artha tvāt  teṣām
translated: Just as the leaves of a tree serve to protect it, so the ritual texts serve to protect the tree of worldly existence, because they reveal dharma, adharma, and their causes and results.

original: yas taṃ yathāvyākhyātaṃ samūlaṃ saṃsāravṛkṣaṃ māyāmayam aśvatthaṃ veda jānāti sa vedavit karmabrahmākhyavedārthavit sa evety arthaḥ
analyzed: yaḥ tam yathā vyākhyātam sa mūlam saṃsāra vṛkṣam māyā mayam aśvattham veda jānāti sa veda vid karma brahma ākhya veda artha vid saḥ eva iti arthaḥ
translated: He who knows that banyan tree of worldly existence, which is composed of illusion, along with its root, as explained, he is a knower of the Veda, a knower of the meaning of the Veda called action and Brahman. The meaning is: he alone.

original: saṃsāravṛkṣasya hi mūlaṃ brahma
analyzed: saṃsāra vṛkṣasya hi mūlam brahma
translated: For the root of the tree of worldly existence is Brahman.

original: hiraṇyagarbhādayaś ca jīvāḥ śākhāsthānīyāḥ /
analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ ca jīvāḥ śākhā sthānīyāḥ
translated: And the individual souls such as Hiraṇyagarbha are like the branches.

original: sa ca saṃsāravṛkṣaḥ svarūpeṇa vinaśvaraḥ pravāharūpeṇa cānantaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca saṃsāra vṛkṣaḥ sva rūpeṇa vinaśvaraḥ pravāha rūpeṇa ca anantaḥ
translated: And that tree of worldly existence is perishable in its own form and infinite in its continuum.

original: sa ca vedoktaiḥ karmabhiḥ sicyate brahmajñānena ca cchidyata ity etāvān eva hi vedārthaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca veda uktaiḥ karmabhiḥ sicyate brahma jñānena ca chidyate iti etāvān eva hi veda arthaḥ
translated: And it is watered by the actions enjoined by the Vedas and cut down by the knowledge of Brahman. This is indeed the sole purpose of the Vedas.

original: yaś ca vedārthavit sa eva sarvavid iti samūlavṛkṣajñānaṃ stauti sa vedavid iti ////
analyzed: yaḥ ca veda artha vid saḥ eva sarva vid iti sa mūlavṛkṣa jñānam stauti sa veda vid iti
translated: And he who knows the meaning of the Vedas is indeed omniscient. Thus he praises the knowledge of the tree with its roots, saying he who knows the Vedas.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: saṃsāracchedako 'saṅga ātmeśāṃśaḥ kṣarākṣarāt /
analyzed: saṃsāra chedakaḥ saṅgaḥ ātma īśa aṃśaḥ kṣara akṣarāt
translated: The part of the Lord of the Self, which cuts off worldly existence, is unattached,

original: uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ iti pañcadaśe kathā //
analyzed: uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ kṛṣṇaḥ iti pañcadaśe kathā
translated: Superior to the perishable and imperishable, is Krishna, in the fifteenth chapter of the story.

original: pūrvādhyāye
analyzed: pūrva adhyāye
translated: In the previous chapter,

original: māṃ ca yo 'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate /
analyzed: mām ca yaḥ vyabhicāreṇa bhakti yogena sevate
translated: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotional yoga,

original: sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahmabhūyāya kalpate //
analyzed: sa guṇān samatītya etān brahma bhūyāya kalpate
translated: Surpasses these qualities and becomes fit for merging into Brahman.

original: Gītā / ity uktam /
analyzed: gītāḥ iti uktam
translated: Gita. Thus it is said.

original: tatra tava manuṣyasya bhaktiyogena kathaṃ brahmabhāva iti cet /
analyzed: tatra tava manuṣyasya bhakti yogena katham brahma bhāvaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is asked how one can attain Brahmanhood by devotional yoga as a human being,

original: satyam ahaṃ manuṣya eva kintu brahmaṇo 'pi tasya pratiṣṭhā paramāśraya ity asya sūtrarūpasya vṛttisthānīyo 'yaṃ pañcadaśādhyāya ārabhyate
analyzed: satyam aham manuṣyaḥ eva kintu tasya pratiṣṭhā parama āśrayaḥ iti asya sūtra rūpasya vṛtti sthānīyaḥ yam pañcadaśa adhyāyaḥ ārabhyate
translated: The fifteenth chapter begins as a commentary on the aphorism that I am indeed a human, but the highest abode of Brahman is also His support.

original: tatra sa guṇān samatītya ity uktam iti guṇamyo 'yaṃ saṃsāraḥ kaḥ /
analyzed: tatra sa guṇān samatītya iti uktam iti yam saṃsāraḥ kaḥ
translated: There it is said, He transcends the qualities. So what is this world of qualities?

original: kuto vāyaṃ pravṛttas tadbhaktyā saṃsāram atikrāmyan jīvo vā kaḥ /
analyzed: kutas vā ayam pravṛttaḥ tad bhaktyā saṃsāram atikrāmyan jīvaḥ vā kaḥ
translated: Or from where has this world originated? Or what is the individual soul who, by devotion to Him, transcends the world?

original: brahmabhūyāya kalpate ity uktaṃ brahma vā kiṃ /
analyzed: brahma bhūyāya kalpate iti uktam brahma vā kim
translated: It is said, He becomes Brahman. So what is Brahman?

original: brahmaṇaḥ pratiṣṭhā tvaṃ vā ka ityādyapekṣāyāṃ prathamam atiśayoktyalaṅkāreṇa saṃsāro 'yam adbhuto 'śvatthavṛkṣa iti varṇayati /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pratiṣṭhā tvam vā kaḥ ityādi apekṣāyām prathamam atiśayokti alaṅkāreṇa saṃsāraḥ yam śvattha vṛkṣaḥ iti varṇayati
translated: Or who are you, the support of Brahman? With this expectation, he first describes this wonderful world as the fig tree, using the figure of speech hyperbole.

original: ūrdhve sarvalokoparitale satyaloke prakṛtibījotthaprathamapraroharūpamahattattvātmakaś caturmukha eka eva mūlaṃ yasya tam /
analyzed: ūrdhve sarva loka uparitale satya loke prakṛti bīja uttha prathama praroha rūpa mahat tattva ātmakaḥ caturmukhaḥ ekaḥ eva mūlam yasya tam
translated: Above, in Satyaloka, the highest world, the four-faced one, who is the first sprout arising from the seed of Prakṛti and is of the nature of the Mahat tattva, is the single root of it.

original: adhaḥ svarbhuvorbhūlokeṣu anantā
analyzed: adhas svar bhuvoḥ bhū lokeṣu anantā
translated: Below, in the worlds of Svar, Bhuva, and Bhur, it is infinite.

original: devagandharvakinnarāsurarākṣasapretabhūtamanuṣyagavāśvādipaśupakṣikṛmikīṭapataṅgasthāvarās
analyzed: deva gandharva kinnara asura rākṣasa preta bhūta manuṣya gavāśva ādi paśu pakṣi kṛmi kīṭa pataṅga sthāvarāḥ
translated: Gods, Gandharvas, Kinnaras, Asuras, Rākṣasas, Pretas, Bhūtas, humans, cows, horses, and other animals, birds, insects, worms, moths, and plants.

original: tāḥ śākhā yasya tam aśvatthaṃ dharmādicaturvargasādhakatvād aśvattham uttamaṃ vṛkṣam /
analyzed: tāḥ śākhāḥ yasya tam aśvattham dharma ādi caturvarga sādhaka tvāt aśvattham uttamam vṛkṣam
translated: That which has those branches is the Ashvattha tree. It is the best tree because it is the means of accomplishing the four goals of human life beginning with Dharma.

original: śleṣeṇa bhaktimatāṃ na śvaḥ sthāsyatīty aśvatthaṃ naṣṭaprāyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: śleṣeṇa bhaktimatām na śvas sthāsyati iti aśvattham naṣṭa prāyam iti arthaḥ
translated: By implication, for the devotees, it is the Ashvattha tree which will not stand tomorrow, meaning it is almost destroyed.

original: abhaktānāṃ tv avyayam anaśvaram /
analyzed: abhaktānām tu avyayam anaśvaram
translated: But for the non-devotees, it is imperishable, not subject to destruction.

original: chandāṃsi vāyavyaṃ śvetam ālabheta bhūmikām aindram ekādaśakapālaṃ nirvapet prajākāmaḥ ity ādyāḥ karmapratipādakā vedāḥ saṃsāravardhakatvāt
analyzed: chandāṃsi vāyavyam śvetam ālabheta bhūmikām aindram ekādaśa kapālam nirvapet prajā kāmaḥ iti ādyāḥ karma pratipādakāḥ vedāḥ saṃsāra vardhaka tvāt
translated: The Vedas which teach actions such as One should sacrifice a white animal to Vayu, one desiring offspring should offer an eleven-pan cake to Indra etc., are the leaves because they promote worldly existence.

original: parṇāni /
analyzed: parṇāni
translated: They are the leaves.

original: vṛkṣo hi parṇaiḥ śobhate /
analyzed: vṛkṣaḥ hi parṇaiḥ śobhate
translated: For a tree shines with its leaves.

original: yas taṃ jānāti sa vedajñaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tam jānāti sa veda jñaḥ
translated: One who knows that is a knower of the Vedas.

original: tathā ca ūrdhvamūlo 'vākśākha eṣo 'śvatthaḥ sanātanaḥ KaṭhU / / iti kaṭhavallīśrutiḥ ////
analyzed: tathā ca ūrdhva mūlaḥ vāc śākhaḥ eṣaḥ śvatthaḥ sanātanaḥ kaṭhu iti kaṭhavallī śrutiḥ
translated: And thus the Katha Upanishad says: This eternal Ashvattha tree has its root above and branches below.

original: baladevaḥ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ
translated: Balarama.

original: saṃsāracchedi vairāgyaṃ jīvo me 'ṃśaḥ sanātanaḥ /
analyzed: saṃsāra chedi vairāgyam jīvaḥ me ṃśaḥ sanātanaḥ
translated: Non-attachment which cuts off worldly existence, the soul is my eternal part,

original: ahaṃ sarvottamaḥ śrīmān iti pañcadaśe smṛtam //
analyzed: aham sarva uttamaḥ śrīmān iti pañcadaśe smṛtam
translated: I am the most excellent of all, and prosperous - this is remembered in the fifteenth.

original: pūrvatra vijñānānandasyautpattikaguṇāṣṭakasyāpi jīvasya karmarūpānādivāsanānuguṇena bhagavatsaṅkalpena prakṛtiguṇasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: pūrvatra vijñāna ānandasya autpattika guṇa aṣṭakasya api jīvasya karma rūpa anādi vāsanā anuguṇena bhagavat saṅkalpena prakṛti guṇa saṅgaḥ
translated: In the previous verse, it is said that the individual soul, which is the bliss of consciousness and has the eight innate qualities, becomes connected with the qualities of Nature in accordance with the Lord's will, which is like karma and has no beginning.

original: sa ca bahuvidhas tadatyayaś ca bhagavadbhaktiśiraskena vivekajñānena bhavet tasmiṃś
analyzed: sa ca bahuvidhaḥ tad atyayaḥ ca bhagavat bhakti śiraskena viveka jñānena bhavet tasmin
translated: And that is of many kinds, and its transcendence is through the knowledge of discrimination, which has devotion to the Lord as its head.

original: ca sati samprāptanijasvarūpo jīvo bhagavantam āśritya prmodo sarvadā tasmiṃs tiṣṭhatīty uktam /
analyzed: ca sati samprāpta nija svarūpaḥ jīvaḥ bhagavantam āśritya prmodo sarvadā tasmin tiṣṭhati iti uktam
translated: And when that exists, the individual soul, having attained its own nature, always dwells in bliss in the Lord, depending on Him. This is what is said.

original: atha tadvivekajñānasthairyakaraṃ vairāgyaṃ jīvasya bhajanīyabhagavadaṃśatvaṃ bhagavataḥ svetarasarvottamatvaṃ cokteṣv artheṣūpayogāya
analyzed: atha tad viveka jñāna sthairya karam vairāgyam jīvasya bhajanīya bhagavat aṃśa tvam bhagavataḥ sva itara sarva uttama tvam ca ukteṣu artheṣu upayogāya
translated: Now, in order to be of use in the matters that have been stated, detachment, which makes firm the knowledge of discrimination of the individual soul, the status of being a part of the Lord who is to be worshipped, and the supremacy of the Lord over all others,

original: pañcadaśe 'smin varṇyate /🔽tatra tāvad guṇaviracitasya saṃsārasya vairāgyavaiccedyatvāt saṃsāraṃ vṛkṣatvena vairāgyaṃ ca śastratvena rūpayan varṇayati bhagavān ūrdhvamūlam
analyzed: pañcadaśe smin varṇyate  tatra tāvat guṇa viracitasya saṃsārasya saṃsāram vṛkṣa tvena vairāgyam ca śastra tvena rūpayan varṇayati bhagavān ūrdhva mūlam
translated: are described in this fifteenth chapter.

original: ity ādibhis tribhiḥ /
analyzed: iti ādibhiḥ tribhiḥ
translated: There, since detachment is the antidote to the world, which is composed of the qualities, the Lord describes the world as a tree and detachment as an axe, with the three verses beginning with The root of the tree of the world is unseen.

original: saṃsārarūpam aśvattham ūrdhvamūlam adhaḥśākhaṃ prāhuḥ /
analyzed: saṃsāra rūpam aśvattham ūrdhva mūlam adhas śākham prāhuḥ
translated: They say that the tree of the world has an unseen root, with branches below and leaves above.

original: ūrdhvaṃ sarvoparisatyaloke pradhānabījotthaprathamapraroharūpamahattattvātmakacaturmukharūpaṃ mūlaṃ yasya saḥ /
analyzed: ūrdhvam sarva upari satyaloke pradhāna bīja uttha prathama praroha rūpa mahat tattva ātmaka caturmukha rūpam mūlam yasya saḥ
translated: Above, in the world of truth, which is above all, the root of which is the form of the four-faced one, consisting of the principle of Mahat, which is the first sprout arising from the primary seed.🔽Below, in the worlds of Svar, Bhuva, and Bhur, which are below the world of truth, the various directions are spread out,

original: adhaḥ satyalokād arvācīneṣu svarbhuvarbhūrlokeṣu devagandharvakinnarāsurayakṣarākṣasamanuṣyapaśupakṣikīṭapataṅgasthāvarāntā nānādikprasṛtatvāc 🔽chākhā yasya tam /
analyzed: adhas satya lokāt arvācīneṣu svar bhuvarbhūḥ lokeṣu deva gandharva kinnara asura yakṣa rākṣasa manuṣya paśu pakṣi kīṭa pataṅga sthāvara antāḥ nānā diś prasṛta tvāt  chākhā yasya tam
translated: such as gods, gandharvas, kinnaras, asuras, yakshas, rakshasas, humans, animals, birds, insects, moths, and immobile beings, which are the branches of which it is the root.

original: caturvargaphalāśrayatvād aśvattham uttamavṛkṣam /
analyzed: caturvarga phala āśraya tvāt aśvattham uttama vṛkṣam
translated: It is the best tree, the Ashvattha, which is the basis for the fruits of the four goals of human life.

original: tādṛśena vivekajñānena vinā nivṛtter abhāvād avyayaṃ pravāharūpeṇa nityaṃ ca /
analyzed: tādṛśena viveka jñānena vinā nivṛtteḥ abhāvāt avyayam pravāha rūpeṇa nityam ca
translated: It is imperishable, eternal in the form of a continuous flow, because without the knowledge of discrimination, there is no cessation.

original: tam āhuḥ śrutayaś cātra
analyzed: tam āhuḥ śrutayaḥ ca atra
translated: The Vedas speak of it here:

original: ūrdhvamūlo 'vākśākha
analyzed: ūrdhva mūlaḥ vāc śākha
translated: The root is above, the branches below,

original: eṣo 'śvatthaḥ sanātanaḥ /
analyzed: eṣa u śvatthaḥ sanātanaḥ
translated: this Ashvattha is eternal.

original: ūrdhvamūlam arvākśākhaṃ
analyzed: ūrdhva mūlam arvāc śākham
translated: The root is above, the branches below,

original: vṛkṣaṃ yo veda samprati //🔽KaṭhU / / ity ādikāḥ /
analyzed: vṛkṣam yaḥ veda samprati  kaṭhu iti ādikāḥ
translated: he who knows the tree as it is now,🔽such as the Katha Upanishad and others.

original: yasya saṃsārāśvatthasya chandāṃsi karmākarmapratipādakāni śrutivākyāni vāsanāārūpatannidānavardhakatvāt
analyzed: yasya saṃsāra aśvatthasya chandāṃsi karma akarma pratipādakāni śruti vākyāni
translated: The desires, which are the Vedic statements that teach action and inaction, are the waters that nourish the tree of worldly existence, because they increase the latent impressions that are their cause.

original: parṇāni prāhus tāni cchandāṃsi vāyavyaṃ śvetam ālabheta bhūtikāma aindram ekādaśakapālaṃ
analyzed: parṇāni prāhuḥ tāni chandāṃsi vāyavyam śvetam ālabheta bhūti kāmaḥ aindram ekādaśa kapālam
translated: Those leaves are said to be the meters. One should offer a white animal to Vayu, desiring prosperity.

original: nirvapet prajākāmaḥ ity ādīni bodhyāni /
analyzed: nirvapet prajā kāmaḥ iti ādīni bodhyāni
translated: One should offer an eleven-kapala oblation to Indra, desiring offspring. Such things should be understood.

original: patrais tarur vardhate śobhate ca tam aśvatthaṃ yo veda yathoktaṃ jānāti sa eva vedavit /
analyzed: patraiḥ taruḥ vardhate śobhate ca tam aśvattham yaḥ veda yathoktam jānāti saḥ eva veda vid
translated: A tree grows and shines with its leaves. Only he who knows that Ashvattha tree as described, who knows it as it is, is indeed a knower of the Vedas.

original: vedaḥ khalu saṃsārasya vṛkṣatvaṃ chedyatvābhiprāyeṇāha tadchedanopāyajño vedārthavid iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: vedaḥ khalu saṃsārasya vṛkṣa tvam chedya tva abhiprāyeṇa āha tad chedana upāya jñaḥ veda artha vid iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The Veda indeed declares the world to be a tree, with the intention of cutting it down. The meaning is that one who knows the purpose of the Veda is one who knows the means of cutting it down.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: adhaś cordhvaṃ prasṛtās tasya śākhā
analyzed: adhas ca ūrdhvam prasṛtāḥ tasya śākhā
translated: Its branches spread upwards and downwards,

original: guṇapravṛddhā viṣayapravālāḥ /🔽adhaś ca mūlāny anusaṃtatāni
analyzed: guṇa pravṛddhāḥ viṣaya pravālāḥ  adhas ca mūlāni anusaṃtatāni
translated: grown with qualities, sprouting with objects.🔽Its roots, connected with actions, spread downwards,

original: karmānubandhīni manuṣyaloke ////
analyzed: karma anubandhīni manuṣya loke
translated: in the human world.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca adhaś ceti /🔽hiraṇyagarbhādayaḥ kāryopādhayo jīvāḥ śākhāsthānīyatvenoktāḥ /
analyzed: ca   ca iti  hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ kārya upādhayaḥ jīvāḥ śākhā sthānīya tvena uktāḥ
translated: Shridhar: And what is more, he says downwards and so on.🔽The individual souls like Hiranyagarbha, who are the limiting adjuncts of effects, are mentioned as being like branches.

original: teṣu ca ye duṣkṛtinas te 'dhaḥ paśvādiyoniṣu prasṛtās tasya saṃsāravṛkṣasya śākhāḥ /
analyzed: teṣu ca ye duṣkṛtinaḥ te dhaḥ paśu ādi yoniṣu prasṛtāḥ tasya saṃsāra vṛkṣasya śākhāḥ
translated: And among them, those who are sinners spread downwards in the wombs of animals and so on, as branches of that tree of worldly existence.

original: kiṃ ca / guṇaiḥ sattvādivṛttibhir jalasecanair iva yathāyathaṃ pravṛddhā vṛddhiṃ prāptāḥ /
analyzed: kim ca guṇaiḥ sattva ādi vṛttibhiḥ jala secanaiḥ iva yathāyatham pravṛddhāḥ vṛddhim prāptāḥ
translated: And further, they are grown, have attained growth, by the qualities, the modifications of sattva etc., like the sprouts by the water-sprinkling.

original: kiṃ ca / viṣayā rūpādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallavasthānīyā yāsāṃ tāḥ /
analyzed: kim ca viṣayāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallava sthānīyāḥ yāsām tāḥ
translated: And further, they have objects, forms etc., as their sprouts, as if they were shoots.

original: śākhāgrasthānīyābhir indriyavṛttibhiḥ saṃyuktatvāt /
analyzed: śākhā agra sthānīyābhiḥ indriya vṛttibhiḥ saṃyukta tvāt
translated: Because they are connected with the modifications of the senses, which are like the tips of the branches.

original: kiṃ ca / adhaś ca caśabdād ūrdhvaṃ ca /
analyzed: kim ca adhas ca caśabdāt ūrdhvam ca
translated: And further, below, and above also, by the word 'ca' (and).

original: mūlāny anusantatāni virūḍhāni /
analyzed: mūlāni anusantatāni virūḍhāni
translated: The roots are continuous, well-established.

original: mukhyaṃ mūlam īśvara eva /
analyzed: mukhyam mūlam īśvaraḥ eva
translated: The principal root is God Himself.

original: imāni tv antarālāni mūlāni tattadbhogavāsanālakṣaṇāni /
analyzed: imāni tu antarālāni mūlāni tad tad bhoga vāsanā lakṣaṇāni
translated: But these intermediate roots are characterized by the latent impressions of the experiences of this and that in the higher and lower worlds.

original: teṣāṃ kāryam āha manuṣyaloke karmānubandhīnīti /
analyzed: teṣām kāryam āha manuṣya loke karma anubandhīni iti
translated: He says their effect: in the world of men, connected with action.

original: karmaivānubandhy uttarakālabhāvi yeṣāṃ tāni /
analyzed: karma eva anubandhi uttara kāla bhāvi yeṣām tāni
translated: Those in which action itself is the connection, that which occurs later.

original: ūrdhvādholokeṣūpabhuktatattadbhogavāsanādibhir
analyzed: ūrdhva adhas lokeṣu upabhukta tad tad bhoga vāsanā ādibhiḥ
translated: For those who have experienced this and that in the higher and lower worlds, by the latent impressions etc.,

original: hi karmakṣaye manuṣyalokaṃ prāptānāṃ tattadanurūpeṣu karmasu pravṛttir bhavati /
analyzed: hi karma kṣaye manuṣya lokam prāptānām tad tad anurūpeṣu karmasu pravṛttiḥ bhavati
translated: when their actions are exhausted, when they attain the world of men, they engage in those and those actions that are in accordance with them.

original: tasminn eva hi karmādhikāro nānyeṣu lokeṣu /
analyzed: tasmin eva hi karma adhikāraḥ na anyeṣu lokeṣu
translated: For in that alone is there the right to action, not in the other worlds.

original: ato manuṣyaloka ity uktam ////
analyzed: atas manuṣya lokaḥ iti uktam
translated: Therefore, it is said 'in the world of men.'

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: tasyaiva saṃsāravṛkṣasyāvayavasambandhiny aparā kalpanocyate adhaś ceti /
analyzed: tasya eva saṃsāra vṛkṣasya avayava sambandhinī aparā kalpanā ucyate adhas ca iti
translated: Another imagination is stated regarding the parts of that very tree of transmigration, beginning with below and so on.

original: pūrvaṃ hiraṇyagarbhādayaḥ kāryopādhayo jīvāḥ śākhāsthānīyatvenoktāḥ /
analyzed: pūrvam hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ kārya upādhayaḥ jīvāḥ śākhā sthānīya tvena uktāḥ
translated: Previously, the individual souls such as Hiranyagarbha, who are the limiting adjuncts of effects, were mentioned as being like the branches.

original: idānīṃ tu tadgato viśeṣa ucyate /
analyzed: idānīm tu tad gataḥ viśeṣaḥ ucyate
translated: But now, a particular aspect of them is being stated.

original: teṣu ye kapūyacaraṇā duṣkṛtinas te 'dhaḥ paśvādiyoniṣu prasṛtā vistāraṃ gatāḥ /
analyzed: teṣu ye kapūya caraṇāḥ duṣkṛtinaḥ te dhar paśu ādi yoniṣu prasṛtāḥ vistāram gatāḥ
translated: Among them, those of impure conduct, the sinners, have spread downwards, extended into the species of animals and so on.

original: ye tu ramaṇīyacaraṇāḥ sukṛtinas ta ūrdhvaṃ devādiyoniṣu prasṛtā ato 'dhaś ca manuṣyatvād
analyzed: ye tu ramaṇīya caraṇāḥ su kṛtinaḥ te ūrdhvam deva ādi yoniṣu prasṛtāḥ atas dhaḥ ca manuṣya tvāt
translated: But those of delightful conduct, the virtuous, have spread upwards, into the species of gods and so on, starting from human birth.

original: ārabhya viriñciparyantam ūrdhvaṃ ca tasmād evārabhya satyalokaparyantaṃ prasṛtās
analyzed: ārabhya viriñci paryantam ūrdhvam ca tasmāt eva ārabhya satyaloka paryantam prasṛtāḥ
translated: And starting from that very [human birth], they have spread upwards up to the world of Satyaloka.

original: tasya saṃsāravṛkṣasya śākhāḥ /
analyzed: tasya saṃsāra vṛkṣasya śākhāḥ
translated: Those are the branches of that tree of transmigration.

original: kīdṛśas tāḥ /
analyzed: kīdṛśaḥ tāḥ
translated: What are they like?

original: guṇaiḥ sattvarajastamo bhir dehendriyaviṣayākārapariṇatair jalasecanair iva pravṛddhāḥ sthūlībhūtāḥ /
analyzed: guṇaiḥ sattva rajaḥ tamobhiḥ deha indriya viṣaya ākāra pariṇataiḥ jala secanaiḥ iva pravṛddhāḥ sthūlībhūtāḥ
translated: They have grown, become thick, by the qualities of sattva, rajas, and tamas, which have transformed into bodies, senses, and objects, like water sprinklings.

original: kiṃ ca / viṣayāḥ śabdādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallavā iva yāsāṃ saṃsāravṛkṣaśākhānāṃ tās tathā śākhāgrasthānīyābhir
analyzed: kim ca viṣayāḥ śabda ādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallavāḥ iva yāsām saṃsāra vṛkṣa śākhānām tāḥ tathā śākhā agra sthānīyābhiḥ
translated: Moreover, those branches of the tree of transmigration, in which the objects such as sound are like sprouts and buds, are like the tips of the branches.

original: indriyavṛttibhiḥ sambandhād rāgādhiṣṭhānatvāc ca /
analyzed: indriya vṛttibhiḥ sambandhāt rāga adhiṣṭhāna tvāt ca
translated: Because of the connection with the functions of the senses, and because of being the basis of attachment.

original: saṃyuktatvāt /
analyzed: saṃyukta tvāt
translated: Because of being connected.

original: kiṃ ca / adhaś ca caśabdād ūrdhvaṃ ca mūlāny avāntarāṇi tattadbhogajanitarāgadveṣādivāsanālakṣaṇāni
analyzed: kim ca adhas ca caśabdāt ūrdhvam ca mūlāni avāntarāṇi tad tad bhoga janita rāga dveṣa ādi vāsanā lakṣaṇāni
translated: Moreover, and below, and above, the intermediate roots, characterized by the latent impressions of attachment, aversion, etc. generated by that and that enjoyment,

original: mūlānīva dharmādharmapravṛttikārakāṇi tasya saṃsāravṛkṣasyānusantatāni anusyūtāni /
analyzed: mūlāni iva dharma adharma pravṛtti kārakāṇi tasya saṃsāra vṛkṣasya anusantatāni anusyūtāni
translated: are continuous, interwoven, like roots, of that tree of worldly existence, which are the causes of the engagement in virtue and vice.

original: mukhyaṃ ca mūlaṃ brahmaiveti na doṣaḥ /
analyzed: mukhyam ca mūlam brahmā eva iti na doṣaḥ
translated: And the principal root is Brahman itself, so there is no fault.

original: kīdṛśāny avāntaramūlāni /
analyzed: kīdṛśāni avāntaramūlāni
translated: What are the intermediate roots like?

original: karma dharmādharmalakṣaṇam anubandhuṃ paścāj janayituṃ śīlaṃ yeṣāṃ tāni karmānubandhīni /
analyzed: karma dharma adharma lakṣaṇam anubandhum paścāt janayitum śīlam yeṣām tāni karma anubandhīni
translated: Those which have the habit of following and generating later on are the roots of action, which are characterized by virtue and vice.

original: kutra / manuṣyaloke manuṣyaś cāsau lokaaś cety adhikṛto brāhmaṇyādiviśiṣṭo deho manuṣyalokas tasmin bāhulyena karmānubandhīni /
analyzed: kutra manuṣya loke manuṣyaḥ ca asau lokaaḥ ca iti adhikṛtaḥ brāhmaṇya ādi viśiṣṭaḥ dehaḥ manuṣya lokaḥ tasmin bāhulyena karma anubandhīni
translated: Where? In the human world. A human being is a person, and the body distinguished by Brahmin status etc. is the human world. In that, the roots of action are mostly.

original: manuṣyāṇāṃ hi karmādhikāraḥ prasiddhaḥ ////
analyzed: manuṣyāṇām hi karma adhikāraḥ prasiddhaḥ
translated: For humans are well known to have the duty of action.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: adhaḥ paśvādiyoniṣu ūrdhve devādiyoniṣu prasṛtās tasya saṃsāravṛkṣasya guṇaiḥ sattvādivṛttibhir jalasekair iva pravṛddhāḥ /
analyzed: adhas paśu ādi yoniṣu ūrdhve deva ādi yoniṣu prasṛtāḥ tasya saṃsāra vṛkṣasya guṇaiḥ sattva ādi vṛttibhiḥ jala sekaiḥ iva pravṛddhāḥ
translated: The roots of that tree of worldly existence extend downwards into the wombs of animals etc. and upwards into the wombs of gods etc. They are nourished by the waters of the modes of nature such as goodness etc., like the growth of a tree by watering.

original: viṣayā śabdādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallavasthānīyā yāsāṃ tāḥ /
analyzed: viṣayā śabda ādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallava sthānīyāḥ yāsām tāḥ
translated: The objects of sense such as sound etc. are the sprouts, which are like leaves, from which they grow.

original: kiṃ ca tasya mūle sarvalokair alakṣito mahānidhiḥ kaścid astīty anumīyate yam eva
analyzed: kim ca tasya mūle sarva lokaiḥ alakṣitaḥ mahā nidhiḥ kaścid asti iti anumīyate yam eva
translated: Moreover, it is inferred that at its root there exists some great treasure unnoticed by all people,🔽relying on which the roots of that ashvattha tree,

original: mūlajaṭābhir avalambya sthitasya tasyāśvatthavṛkṣasyāpi baṭavṛkṣasyeva śākhāsv🔽api bāhyā jaṭāḥ santīty āha adhaś ceti /
analyzed: mūla jaṭābhiḥ avalambya sthitasya tasya aśvattha vṛkṣasya api baṭa vṛkṣasya iva śākhāsu  api bāhyāḥ jaṭāḥ santi iti āha adhas ca iti
translated: which stands with external matted locks on its branches like a banyan tree, are also extended downwards.

original: brahmalokamūlasyāpi tasyādhaś ca manuṣyaloke karmānubandhīni karmānulambīni mūlāny anusantatāni nirantaraṃ vistṛtāni bhavanti /
analyzed: brahma loka mūlasya api tasya adhas ca manuṣya loke karma anubandhīni karma anulambīni mūlāni anusantatāni nirantaram vistṛtāni bhavanti
translated: And below, in the human world, the roots connected with action are continuously extended, uninterruptedly spread out,

original: karmaphalānāṃ yatas tato bhogānte punar manuṣyajanmany eva karmasu pravṛttāni bhavantīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: karma phalānām yatas tatas bhoga ante punar manuṣya janmani eva karmasu pravṛttāni bhavanti iti arthaḥ
translated: from which the fruits of action are enjoyed, and at the end of enjoyment they again become engaged in actions in human birth. This is the meaning.

original: baladevaḥ / kiṃ cādha iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ kim ca adhas iti
translated: Balarama. Moreover, below, etc.

original: tasyoktalakṣaṇasya saṃsārāśvatthasya śākhā adha ūrdhvaṃ ca prasṛtāḥ /
analyzed: tasya ukta lakṣaṇasya saṃsāra aśvatthasya śākhāḥ adhas ūrdhvam ca prasṛtāḥ
translated: The branches of that Ashvattha tree, whose characteristics have been described, extend upwards and downwards.

original: adho manuṣyapaśvādiyoniṣu duṣkṛtair ūrdhvaṃ ca devagandharvādiyoniṣu sukṛtair vistṛtāḥ /
analyzed: adhas manuṣya paśu ādi yoniṣu duṣkṛtaiḥ ūrdhvam ca deva gandharva ādi yoniṣu sukṛtaiḥ vistṛtāḥ
translated: Downwards, they spread out in the forms of human beings, animals, etc., through evil deeds; and upwards, they spread out in the forms of gods, Gandharvas, etc., through good deeds.

original: guṇaiḥ sattvādivṛttibhir ambuniṣekair iva pravṛddhāḥ sthaulyabhājaḥ /🔽viṣayāḥ śabdasparśādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallavā yāsāṃ tāḥ /
analyzed: guṇaiḥ sattva ādi vṛttibhiḥ ambu niṣekaiḥ iva pravṛddhāḥ sthaulya bhājaḥ  viṣayāḥ śabda sparśa ādayaḥ pravālāḥ pallavāḥ yāsām tāḥ
translated: They are thick, having grown by means of the qualities such as sattva, etc., like the growth of a tree by means of watering.🔽The objects of sense such as sound, touch, etc., are the sprouts, and those which have them are so described.

original: śākhāgrasthānīyābhiḥ śrotrādivṛttibhir yogād rāgādhiṣṭhānatvāc ca śabdādīnāṃ pallavasthānīyatvam /
analyzed: śākhā agra sthānīyābhiḥ śrotra ādi vṛttibhiḥ yogāt rāga adhiṣṭhāna tvāt ca śabda ādīnām pallava sthānīya tvam
translated: The sense-organs such as the ear, etc., which are like the tips of the branches, are connected with them, and the objects of sense such as sound, etc., are like the sprouts, because they are the basis of attachment.

original: tasyāśvatthasyādhaś ca śabdād ūrdhvaṃ cāvāntarāṇi mūlāny anusantatāni vistṛtāni santi /
analyzed: tasya aśvatthasya adhas ca śabdāt ūrdhvam ca avāntarāṇi mūlāni anusantatāni vistṛtāni santi
translated: Below that Ashvattha tree, and above, there are intermediate roots that extend and spread out.

original: tāni ca tattadbhogajanitarāgadveṣādivāsanārūpāṇi dharmādharmapravṛttikāritvān mūlatulyāny ucyante /
analyzed: tāni ca tad tad bhoga janita rāga dveṣa ādi vāsanā rūpāṇi dharma adharma pravṛtti kāri tvāt mūla tulyāni ucyante
translated: And those are said to be like the roots, because they cause the performance of virtuous and non-virtuous actions in the form of the latent impressions of attachment, aversion, etc., produced by the enjoyment of those objects.

original: mukhyaṃ mūlaṃ tādṛk caturmukhas tattadvāsanās tv avāntaramūlāni nyagrodhasyaiva jaṭopajaṭāvṛndānīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: mukhyam mūlam tādṛś caturmukhaḥ tad tad vāsanāḥ tu avāntara mūlāni nyagrodhasya eva jaṭā upajaṭā vṛndāni iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The principal root is the four-faced one (Brahma), and the intermediate roots are the groups of secondary and tertiary roots of the very same banyan tree, in the form of the latent impressions of those (actions). This is the idea.

original: tāni kīdṛśānīty āha manuṣyaloke karmānubandhīni yatas tataḥ karmaphalabhogāvasāne sati punar manuṣyaloke karmahetubhūtāni bhavantīty
analyzed: tāni kīdṛśāni iti āha manuṣya loke karma anubandhīni yatas tatas karma phala bhoga avasāne sati punar manuṣya loke karma hetu bhūtāni bhavanti iti
translated: How are they? He says: They are in the human world, connected with karma, because from there, when the enjoyment of the fruits of karma is over, they become the causes of karma again in the human world.

original: sa lokaḥ khalu karmabhūmir iti prasiddham ////
analyzed: sa lokaḥ khalu karma bhūmiḥ iti prasiddham
translated: That world is indeed well-known as the land of karma.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate
analyzed: na rūpam asya iha tathā upalabhyate
translated: Its form is not perceived here in this way,

original: nānto na cādir na ca saṃpratiṣṭhā /🔽aśvattham enaṃ suvirūḍhamūlam
analyzed: na antaḥ na ca ādiḥ na ca saṃpratiṣṭhā  aśvattham enam su virūḍha mūlam
translated: It has no end, no beginning, and no foundation.🔽Having cut down this ashvattha tree with its roots well-established

original: asaṅgaśastreṇa dṛḍhena chittvā ////
analyzed: asaṅga śastreṇa dṛḍhena chittvā
translated: With the firm weapon of non-attachment,

original: tataḥ padaṃ tatparimārgitavyaṃ
analyzed: tatas padam tat parimārgitavyam
translated: Then that state should be sought,

original: yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ /🔽tam eva cādyaṃ puruṣaṃ prapadye
analyzed: yasmin gatāḥ na nivartanti bhūyas  tam eva ca ādyam puruṣam prapadye
translated: Having gone to which one does not return again.🔽And I take refuge in that very primordial Purusha,

original: yataḥ pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā purāṇī ////
analyzed: yatas pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā purāṇī
translated: From whom the ancient activity has spread out.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca /
translated: Shridhar: And what?

original: na rūpam iti /
analyzed: na rūpam iti
translated: Not form, etc.

original: iha saṃsāre sthitaiḥ prāṇibhir asya saṃsāravṛkṣasya tathordhvamūlatvādiprakāreṇa rūpaṃ nopalabhyate /🔽na cānto 'vasānam aparyaptatvāt /
analyzed: iha saṃsāre sthitaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ asya saṃsāra vṛkṣasya tathā ūrdhva mūla tva ādi prakāreṇa rūpam na upalabhyate  na ca antar vasānam a paryapta tvāt
translated: The form of this tree of worldly existence, situated in this world, is not perceived in this way, with its roots above, etc.

original: na cādir anāditvāt /
analyzed: na ca ādiḥ an ādi tvāt
translated: And it has no end, no conclusion, because it is endless.🔽And it has no beginning, because it is beginningless.

original: na ca sampratiṣṭhā sthitiḥ /
analyzed: na ca sampratiṣṭhā sthitiḥ
translated: And it has no foundation, no stability.

original: kathaṃ tiṣṭhatīti nopalabhyate /
analyzed: katham tiṣṭhati iti na upalabhyate
translated: How it stands is not perceived.

original: yasmād evambhūto 'yaṃ saṃsāravṛkṣo durucchedo 'narthakaraś ca tasmād enaṃ dṛḍhena vairāgyena śastreṇa cchitvā tattvajñāne yatetety āha aśvattham
analyzed: yasmāt evambhūtaḥ yam saṃsāra vṛkṣaḥ durucchedaḥ nartha karaḥ ca tasmāt enam dṛḍhena vairāgyena śastreṇa chitvā tattva jñāne yateta iti āha aśvattham
translated: Since this world-tree is thus, difficult to cut down and harmful, therefore, having cut it down with the weapon of firm detachment, one should strive for the knowledge of reality. Thus it is said:

original: enam iti sārdhena /
analyzed: enam iti sārdhena
translated: This with the half verse.

original: enam aśvatthaṃ suvirūḍhamūlam atyantabaddhamūlaṃ santam /
analyzed: enam aśvattham su virūḍha mūlam atyanta baddha mūlam santam
translated: This fig tree, which has very deep roots, extremely firm roots,

original: asaṅgaḥ saṅgarāhityam ahaṃmamatātyāgaḥ /
analyzed: asaṅgaḥ saṅga rāhityam aham mamatā tyāgaḥ
translated: Without attachment means being free from attachment, giving up the sense of I and mine.

original: tena śastreṇa dṛḍhena samyagvicāreṇa cchittvā pṛthakkṛtya ////
analyzed: tena śastreṇa dṛḍhena samyak vicāreṇa chittvā pṛthakkṛtya
translated: Having cut it down, having separated it, with that weapon, with the firm weapon of right consideration.

original: tata iti / tataś tasya mūlabhūtaṃ tat padaṃ vastu parimārgitavyam anveṣṭavyaṃ /
analyzed: tatas iti tatas tasya mūla bhūtam tat padam vastu parimārgitavyam anveṣṭavyam
translated: Then means after that, that state which is the root of that should be sought, should be searched for.

original: kīdṛśaṃ / yasmin gatā yat padaṃ prāptāḥ santo bhūyo na nivartanti nāvartanta ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kīdṛśam yasmin gatāḥ yat padam prāptāḥ santaḥ bhūyas na nivartanti na āvartante iti arthaḥ
translated: What kind of? That state which, having gone to which, having attained which, the righteous do not return again, the meaning is that they do not come back.

original: anveṣaṇaprakāram evāha tam eveti /
analyzed: anveṣaṇa prakāram eva āha tam eva iti
translated: He states the manner of searching: Him alone.

original: yata eṣā purāṇī cirantanī saṃsārapravṛttiḥ prasṛtā vistṛtā /
analyzed: yatas eṣā purāṇī cirantanī saṃsāra pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā vistṛtā
translated: Since this ancient, long-standing worldly activity has spread, has expanded.

original: tam eva cādyaṃ puruṣaṃ prapadye śaraṇaṃ vrajāmi /
analyzed: tam eva ca ādyam puruṣam prapadye śaraṇam vrajāmi
translated: And I take refuge in that very primordial Person, I go for shelter.

original: ity evam ekāntabhaktyānveṣṭavyam ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: iti evam ekānta bhaktyā anveṣṭavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it should be searched for with such exclusive devotion.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: yas tv ayaṃ saṃsāravṛkṣo varṇita iha saṃsāre sthitaiḥ prāṇibhir asya saṃsāravṛkṣasya
analyzed: yaḥ tu ayam saṃsāra vṛkṣaḥ varṇitaḥ iha saṃsāre sthitaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ asya saṃsāra vṛkṣasya
translated: But this tree of transmigration, which has been described here, for those who are in transmigration,

original: tathordhvamūlatvādi tathā tena prakāreṇa rūpaṃ nopalabhyate svapnamarīcyudakamāyāgandharvanagaravan
analyzed: tathā ūrdhva mūla tva ādi tathā tena prakāreṇa rūpam na upalabhyate svapna marīci udaka māyā gandharvanagara van
translated: its form is not perceived in that way, with its roots above and so on, like a dream, a mirage, water, a magical creation, a gandharva city,

original: mṛṣātvena dṛṣṭanaṣṭasvarūpatvāt tasya /
analyzed: mṛṣātvena dṛṣṭa naṣṭa svarūpa tvāt tasya
translated: because its nature, seen as false, is destroyed.

original: ata eva tasyānto 'vasānam nopalabhyate /
analyzed: atas eva tasya antaḥ vasānam na upalabhyate
translated: For this very reason, its end, its conclusion, is not perceived.

original: etāvatā kālena samāptiṃ gamiṣyatīti aparyaptatvāt /
analyzed: etāvatā kālena samāptim gamiṣyati iti a paryapta tvāt
translated: Because it does not come to an end in so much time, it is not sufficient.

original: na cāsyādir upalabhyate /
analyzed: na ca asya ādiḥ upalabhyate
translated: And its beginning is not perceived.

original: ita ārabhya pravṛtta ity anāditvāt /
analyzed: itas ārabhya pravṛttaḥ iti anādi tvāt
translated: Because it has no beginning, it is said to have begun from here.

original: na ca sampratiṣṭhā sthitir madhyamasthopalabhyate /
analyzed: na ca sampratiṣṭhā sthitiḥ madhyama sthā upalabhyate
translated: And its middle, its stability, is not perceived.

original: ādyantapratiyogikatvāt tasya /
analyzed: ādi anta pratiyogika tvāt tasya
translated: Because that is opposed to the beginning and end.

original: yasmād evaṃbhūto 'yaṃ saṃsāravṛkṣo durucchedaḥ sarvānarthakaraś ca tasmād anādyajñānena
analyzed: yasmāt evaṃbhūtaḥ yam saṃsāra vṛkṣaḥ durucchedaḥ sarva anartha karaḥ ca tasmāt anādyajñānena
translated: Since this tree of transmigration is thus, being difficult to cut down and causing all harm, therefore, with beginningless ignorance,

original: suvirūḍhamūlam atyantabaddhamūlaṃ prāguktam aśvatthaṃ asaṅgaśastreṇa saṅgaḥ
analyzed: su virūḍha mūlam atyanta baddha mūlam prāc uktam aśvattham asaṅga śastreṇa saṅgaḥ
translated: it is said to be well-established in its roots, with roots bound to the extreme, the fig tree described earlier, with the weapon of non-attachment, attachment

original: spṛhāsaṅgaḥ saṅgavirodhi vairāgyaṃ putravittalokaiṣaṇātyāgarūpaṃ tad eva śastraṃ
analyzed: spṛhā saṅgaḥ saṅga virodhi vairāgyam putra vitta loka eṣaṇā tyāga rūpam tat eva śastram
translated: The weapon of non-attachment is the same as the renunciation which is the opposite of attachment and consists in giving up the pursuit of sons, wealth and worlds.

original: rāgadveṣamayasaṃsāravirodhitvāt /
analyzed: rāga dveṣa maya saṃsāra virodhi tvāt
translated: It is so called because it is opposed to the worldly life which consists in attachment and aversion.

original: tenāsaṅgaśastreṇa dṛḍhena paramātmajñānautsukhyadṛḍhīkṛtena punaḥ punar vivekābhyāsaniśitena
analyzed: tena asaṅga śastreṇa dṛḍhena paramātma jñāna autsukhya dṛḍhīkṛtena punar punar viveka abhyāsa niśitena
translated: With that firm weapon of non-attachment, which is made firm by the eagerness for the knowledge of the Supreme Self, and which is sharpened by the repeated practice of discrimination,

original: cchittvā samūlam uddhṛtya vairāgyaśamadamādisampattyā sarvakarmasaṃnyāsaṃ kṛtvety etat // //
analyzed: chittvā sa mūlam uddhṛtya vairāgya śama dama ādi sampattyā sarva karma saṃnyāsam kṛtvā iti etat
translated: one should cut off (the worldly life) along with its roots and uproot it, and then, by the perfection of non-attachment, self-control, tranquility etc., one should renounce all actions. This is the meaning.

original: tato gurum upasṛtya tato 'śvatthād ūrdhvaṃ vyavasthitaṃ tad vaiṣṇavaṃ padaṃ vedāntavākyavicāreṇa
analyzed: tatas gurum upasṛtya śvatthāt ūrdhvam vyavasthitam tat vaiṣṇavam padam vedānta vākya vicāreṇa
translated: Then, having approached the teacher, that abode of Vishnu, which is situated above the fig tree, should be sought by the investigation of the Vedanta passages.

original: parimārgitavyaṃ mārgayitavyam anveṣṭavyaṃ so 'nveṣṭabhyaḥ sa vijijñāsitavya iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: parimārgitavyam mārgayitavyam anveṣṭavyam saḥ nu eṣṭabhyaḥ sa vijijñāsitavyaḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: It should be sought, it should be sought after, it should be desired to be known, as stated in the Upanishad.

original: tat padaṃ śravaṇādinā jñātavyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tat padam śravaṇa ādinā jñātavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that that abode should be known by hearing etc.

original: kiṃ tat padaṃ yasmin pade gatāḥ praviṣṭā jñānena na nivartanti nāvartante bhūyaḥ punaḥ saṃsārāya /
analyzed: kim tat padam yasmin pade gatāḥ praviṣṭāḥ jñānena na nivartanti na āvartante bhūyas punar saṃsārāya
translated: What is that abode, having entered which, having gone into that abode by knowledge, they do not return, do not come back again to worldly life?

original: kathaṃ tat parimārgitavyam /
analyzed: katham tat parimārgitavyam
translated: How should that be sought?

original: ity āha yaḥ padaśabdenoktas tam eva cādyam ādau bhavaṃ puruṣaṃ yenedaṃ sarvaṃ
analyzed: iti āha yaḥ pada śabdena uktaḥ tam eva ca ādyam ādau bhavam puruṣam yena idam sarvam
translated: Thus, he who is spoken of by the word 'pada' (step), and that very first, primordial Purusha by whom this all

original: pūrṇaṃ taṃ puruṣu pūrṣu vā śayānaṃ prapadye śaraṇaṃ gato 'smīty evaṃ tadekaśaraṇatayā
analyzed: pūrṇam tam puruṣu pūrṣu vā śayānam prapadye śaraṇam gataḥ smi iti evam tad eka śaraṇa tayā
translated: is full, I resort to that Purusha, lying in the Pūrvas (East), I have gone for refuge, thus, by being solely dependent on Him,

original: tad anveṣṭavyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tat anveṣṭavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that He should be sought after.

original: taṃ kaṃ puruṣaṃ /
analyzed: tam kam puruṣam
translated: What is that Purusha?

original: yato yasmāt puruṣāt pravṛttir māyāmayasaṃsāravṛkṣapravṛttiḥ purāṇī cirantany anādir eṣā prasṛtā niḥsṛtaindrajālikād iva māyāhastyādi
analyzed: yatas yasmāt puruṣāt pravṛttiḥ māyā maya saṃsāra vṛkṣa pravṛttiḥ purāṇī cirantanī anādiḥ eṣā prasṛtā niḥsṛtā aindrajālikāt iva māyā hasti ādi
translated: From whom, from which Purusha, the ancient, long-standing, beginningless, this origination of the world of transmigration consisting of Maya has proceeded, like a magic show from a magician.

original: taṃ puruṣaṃ prapadya ity anvayaḥ ////
analyzed: tam puruṣam prapadye iti anvayaḥ
translated: The sense is that I resort to that Purusha.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: kiṃ ceha manuṣyaloke 'sya rūpaṃ svarūpaṃ tathā saniścayaṃ nopalabhyate satyo 'yaṃ mithyāyaṃ nityo 'yam iti vādimatavaividhyād iti bhāvaḥ
analyzed: kim ca iha manuṣya loke rūpam sva rūpam tathā sa niścayam nā upalabhyate satyaḥ yam mithyā ayam nityaḥ yam iti vādi mata vaividhyāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Moreover, in this human world, His form, His nature, and His true nature are not perceived with certainty, whether He is true or false, whether He is eternal or not, due to the diversity of opinions.

original: na cānto 'paryantatvān na cādir anāditvān na ca sampratiṣṭhāśrayaḥ /
analyzed: na ca antaḥ paryanta tvāt na ca ādiḥ anādi tvāt na ca sampratiṣṭhā āśrayaḥ
translated: And He has no end, because He is infinite, no beginning, because He is beginningless, and no basis.

original: kiṃ vādhāraḥ ko 'yam ity api nopalabhyate tattvajñānābhāvād iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: kim vā ādhāraḥ kaḥ yam iti api nā upalabhyate tattva jñāna abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Or, no support, no one knows what He is, due to the absence of true knowledge.

original: yathā tathāyaṃ bhavatu jīvamātraduḥkhaikanidānasyāsya chedakaṃ śastram asaṅgaṃ jñātvā tenaitaṃ chittvaivāsya mūlatalastho mahānidhir anveṣṭavya
analyzed: yathā tathā ayam bhavatu jīva mātra duḥkha eka nidānasya asya chedakam śastram asaṅgam jñātvā tena etam chittvā eva asya mūla tala sthaḥ mahā nidhiḥ
translated: Let this be so. Having known the unattached sword that cuts off the sole cause of the suffering of mere existence, having cut it off with that very sword, one should search for the great treasure that exists at its root.

original: ity āha aśvattham iti /
analyzed: iti āha aśvattham iti
translated: Thus it is said: The ashvattha tree.

original: asaṅgo 'nāsaktiḥ sarvatra vairāgyam iti yāvat tena śastreṇa kuṭhāreṇa cchitvā svataḥ pṛthakkṛtya tatas tasya mūlabhūtaṃ tatpadaṃ vastu mahānidhirūpaṃ
analyzed: asaṅgaḥ na āsaktiḥ sarvatra vairāgyam iti yāvat tena śastreṇa kuṭhāreṇa chitvā svatas pṛthakkṛtya tatas tasya mūla bhūtam tat padam vastu mahā nidhi rūpam
translated: Having cut it with that sword, that axe, having separated it by itself, then that state which is its root, which is like a great treasure,

original: brahma parimārgitavyam /
analyzed: brahma parimārgitavyam
translated: Brahman should be sought.

original: kīdṛśaṃ tad ata āha yasmin gatā yat padaṃ prāptāḥ santo bhūyo na nivartante na cāvartanta ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kīdṛśam tat atas āha yasmin gatāḥ yat padam prāptāḥ santaḥ bhūyas na nivartante na ca āvartante iti arthaḥ
translated: What is that like? Therefore it is said: In which, having gone, having attained that state, the good do not return again, the meaning is that they do not return.

original: anveṣaṇaprakāram
analyzed: anveṣaṇa prakāram
translated: The method of searching

original: āha yata eṣā purāṇī cirantanī saṃsārapravṛttiḥ prasṛtā vistṛtā tam evādyaṃ puruṣaṃ prapadye bhajāmīti bhaktyā anveṣṭavyam ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: āha yatas eṣā purāṇī cirantanī saṃsāra pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā vistṛtā tam eva ādyam puruṣam prapadye bhajāmi iti bhaktyā anveṣṭavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: is said: From which this ancient, long-standing worldly activity has spread, has expanded, to that primeval person I resort, I serve, with devotion, the meaning is that it should be sought.

original: baladevaḥ / na rūpam iti asyāśvatthasya rūpam iha manuṣyaloke tathā nopalabhyate yathordhvamūlatvādidharmakatayā mayopavarṇitam /
analyzed: baladevaḥ na rūpam iti asya aśvatthasya rūpam iha manuṣya loke tathā na upalabhyate yathā ūrdhva mūla tva ādi dharmaka tayā mayā upavarṇitam
translated: Baladeva: The form is not seen - the form of this fig tree is not seen here in the human world as described by me with the characteristics of having roots above, etc.

original: na cāsyānto nāśa upalalabhyate /
analyzed: na ca asya antaḥ nāśaḥ upalalabhyate
translated: And its end, destruction, is not perceived.

original: katham ayaṃ anarthavrātajaṭilo vinaśyed iti na jñāyate /
analyzed: katham ayam anartha vrāta jaṭilaḥ vinaśyet iti na jñāyate
translated: How this tangled mass of misfortune will perish is not known.

original: na cāsyādikāraṇam upalabhyate /
analyzed: na ca asya ādi kāraṇam upalabhyate
translated: And its beginning cause is not perceived.

original: kuto 'yam īdṛśo jāto 'stīti /
analyzed: kutas yam īdṛśaḥ jātaḥ sti iti
translated: From where did such a one arise?

original: na cāsya sampratiṣṭhā samāśrayo 'py upalabhyate /
analyzed: na ca asya sampratiṣṭhā samāśrayā u pi upalabhyate
translated: And its support, its basis, is also not perceived.

original: kiṃ samāśrayo 'yaṃ satiṣṭhat iti /
analyzed: kim samāśrayaḥ yam satiṣṭhat iti
translated: On what is this one based?

original: kintu manusyoo 'haṃ putro yajñadattasya / /
analyzed: kintu ham putraḥ yajñadattasya
translated: But only this much is known: I am a human, the son of Yajnadatta.

original: pitā ca devadattasya /
analyzed: pitā ca devadattasya
translated: And the father of Devadatta.

original: tadanurūpakarmakārī sukhī duḥkhī /
analyzed: tad anurūpa karma kārī sukhī duḥkhī
translated: Engaged in such and such actions, happy, unhappy.

original: sāsmin deśe 'smin grāme nivasāmīty etāvad eva vijñāyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sā asmin deśe smin grāme nivasāmi iti etāvat eva vijñāyate iti arthaḥ
translated: I reside in this country, in this village. This is the meaning.

original: yasmād evaṃ durbodho 'narthavrate hetuś cāyam aśvatthas tasmāt satprasaṅgalabdhavastuyāthātmyajñānenainam
analyzed: yasmāt evam durbodhaḥ nartha vrate hetuḥ ca ayam aśvatthaḥ tasmāt sat prasaṅga labdha vastu yāthātmya jñānena enam
translated: Since this fig tree is thus difficult to understand and is the cause of a mass of misfortune, therefore, by the knowledge of the true nature of things obtained through association with the good,

original: asaṅgaśastreṇa vairāgyakuṭhāreṇa dṛḍhena vivekābhyāsaniśitena cchitvā svataḥ pṛthakkṛtya
analyzed: asaṅga śastreṇa vairāgya kuṭhāreṇa dṛḍhena viveka abhyāsa niśitena chitvā svatas pṛthakkṛtya
translated: Having cut off with the weapon of non-attachment, the axe of detachment, firm and sharp through the practice of discrimination, having separated it from itself,

original: tat padaṃ parimārgitavyam iti pareṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: tat padam parimārgitavyam iti pareṇa anvayaḥ
translated: that state should be sought out. This is the connection with the next verse.

original: saṅgo viṣayābhilāṣas tadvirodhy asaṅgo vairāgyaṃ /
analyzed: saṅgaḥ viṣaya abhilāṣaḥ tad virodhi asaṅgaḥ vairāgyam
translated: Attachment is the desire for objects. Its opposite, non-attachment, is detachment.

original: tad eva śastraṃ tadabhilāṣanāśakatvāt suvirūḍhamūlaṃ pūrvoktarītyātyantaṃ baddhamūlam /
analyzed: tat eva śastram tad abhilāṣa nāśaka tvāt su virūḍha mūlam pūrva ukta rītyā atyantam baddha mūlam
translated: That itself is the weapon, because it destroys the desire for objects. It is well-rooted, having very firm roots, in the manner described earlier.

original: tataḥ saṃsārāśvatthamūlād uparisthitaṃ tat padaṃ parimārgitavyaṃ matprasaṅgalabdhaiḥ śravaṇādibhiḥ sādhanair anveṣṭavyam /
analyzed: tatas saṃsāra aśvattha mūlāt upari sthitam tat padam parimārgitavyam mad prasaṅga labdhaiḥ śravaṇa ādibhiḥ sādhanaiḥ anveṣṭavyam
translated: From that root of the world-tree, that state which is above should be sought out, should be investigated by the means such as hearing and so on obtained through devotion to Me.

original: tat padaṃ kīdṛśaṃ tatrāha yasminn iti /
analyzed: tat padam kīdṛśam tatra āha yasmin iti
translated: What is that state like? In that regard it is said: In which...

original: yasmin gatās taiḥ sādhanair yat prāptā janās tato na nivartante svargād iva na patanti /
analyzed: yasmin gatāḥ taiḥ sādhanaiḥ yat prāptāḥ janāḥ tatas na nivartante svargāt iva na patanti
translated: In which, having gone to which by those means, people who have attained it do not return from there, do not fall, like from heaven.

original: mārgaṇavidhim āha tam eveti /
analyzed: mārgaṇa vidhim āha tam eva iti
translated: The method of seeking it is stated: That...

original: yataḥ purāṇī cirantanīyaṃ jagatpravṛttiḥ prasṛtā vistṛtā /
analyzed: yatas purāṇī cirantanīyam jagat pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā vistṛtā
translated: From which the ancient, long-standing, worldly activity has spread out, has expanded.

original: tam eva cādyaṃ puruṣaṃ prapadye śaraṇaṃ vrajāmīti prapattipūrvakaiḥ śravaṇādibhis tanmārgaṇam uktam /
analyzed: tam eva ca ādyam puruṣam prapadye śaraṇam vrajāmi iti prapatti pūrvakaiḥ śravaṇa ādibhiḥ tat mārgaṇam uktam
translated: And the seeking of Him alone, the Supreme Person, is stated by the words, I take refuge in Him, etc., which are preceded by the act of taking refuge.

original: yo jagaddhetur yatporapattyā saṃsāranivṛttiḥ sa khalu kṛṣṇa eva ahaṃ sarvasya prabhavaḥ ity ādeḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ jagat hetuḥ saṃsāra nivṛttiḥ sa khalu kṛṣṇaḥ eva aham sarvasya prabhavaḥ iti ādeḥ
translated: That Kṛṣṇa alone is the cause of the universe and by devotion to Him there is cessation of worldly existence, because of such statements as I am the origin of all and so on,

original: daivī hy eṣā guṇamayī ity ādeś ca tadukteḥ /🔽na tad bhāsayata ity ādinā vyaktībhāvitvāc ca ////
analyzed: daivī hi eṣā guṇa mayī iti ādeḥ ca tad ukteḥ  na tat bhāsayate iti ādinā vyaktībhāvi tvāt ca
translated: and because of the statement For this is God's own nature, consisting of the three qualities (14.3),

original: BhG /🔽nirmānamohā jitasaṅgadoṣā
analyzed: bhg  nirmāna mohā jita saṅga doṣā
translated: and because of the statement beginning with That does not shine (15.6), etc., because of the manifestation of that.🔽The Blessed Lord said --🔽Those who are free from pride, delusion, and the fault of attachment,

original: adhyātmanityā vinivṛttakāmāḥ /
analyzed: adhyātma nityāḥ vinivṛtta kāmāḥ
translated: who are ever devoted to the Self, whose desires have ceased,

original: dvandvair vimuktāḥ sukhaduḥkhasaṃjñair
analyzed: dvandvaiḥ vimuktāḥ sukha duḥkha saṃjñaiḥ
translated: who are released from the pairs, such as pleasure and pain,

original: gacchanty amūḍhāḥ padam avyayaṃ tat ////
analyzed: gacchanti amūḍhāḥ padam avyayam tat
translated: they, being undeluded, go to that imperishable state.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tatprāptau sādhanāntarāṇi darśayann āha nirmāneti /
translated: Śrīdhara: Showing other means for attaining that [imperishable state], the Lord says, Those who are free from pride, etc.

original: nirgatau mānamohau ahaṅkāramithyātisiveśau yebhyas te /
analyzed: nirgatau māna mohau ahaṅkāra mithyā ati siva īśau yebhyaḥ te
translated: Those who are free from pride and delusion, i.e., egoism and false knowledge,

original: jitaḥ putrādisaṅgarūpo doṣo yais te /
analyzed: jitaḥ putra ādi saṅga rūpaḥ doṣaḥ yaiḥ te
translated: those who have conquered the faults in the form of attachment to sons and so on,

original: adhyātma ātmajñāne nityāḥ pariniṣṭhitāḥ /
analyzed: adhyātma ātma jñāne nityāḥ pariniṣṭhitāḥ
translated: who are ever devoted to the Self, i.e., to the knowledge of the Self,

original: viśeṣeṇa nivṛttaḥ kāmo yebhyas te /
analyzed: viśeṣeṇa nivṛttaḥ kāmaḥ yebhyaḥ te
translated: those whose desires have ceased in particular,

original: sukhaduḥkhahetutvāt sukhaduḥkhasaṃjñāni śītoṣṇādīni dvandvāni /
analyzed: sukha duḥkha hetu tvāt sukha duḥkha saṃjñāni śīta uṣṇa ādīni dvandvāni
translated: The pairs of opposites such as cold and heat are called pleasure and pain because they are the causes of pleasure and pain.

original: tair vimuktāḥ /
analyzed: taiḥ vimuktāḥ
translated: They are free from them.

original: ata evāmūḍhā nivṛtāvidyāḥ santaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva amūḍhāḥ nivṛta avidyāḥ santaḥ
translated: And for that very reason, being undeluded, free from the obscuration of ignorance,

original: tad avyayaṃ padaṃ gacchanti ////
analyzed: tat avyayam padam gacchanti
translated: they go to that imperishable state.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: parimārgaṇapūrvakaṃ vaiṣṇavaṃ padaṃ gacchatām aṅgāntarāṇy āha nirmāṇeti /
analyzed: parimārgaṇa pūrvakam vaiṣṇavam padam gacchatām aṅga antarāṇi āha nirmāṇa iti
translated: For those who go to the Vaishnava state after first searching for it, he mentions the subsidiary limbs beginning with creation.

original: māno 'haṅkāro garvaḥ /
analyzed: mānaḥ haṅkāraḥ garvaḥ
translated: Pride is egoism, arrogance.

original: mohas tv aviveko viparyayo vā /
analyzed: mohaḥ tu avivekaḥ viparyayaḥ vā
translated: Delusion is lack of discrimination or error.

original: tābhyāṃ niṣkrāntā nirmānamohāḥ /
analyzed: tābhyām niṣkrāntāḥ nirmāna mohāḥ
translated: They are free from those two, being without pride and delusion.

original: tau nirgatau yebhyas te vā /
analyzed: tau nirgatau yebhyaḥ te vā
translated: Or they are those from whom those two have departed.

original: tathāhaṅkārāvivekābhyāṃ rahitā iti yāvat /
analyzed: tathā ahaṅkāra avivekābhyām rahitāḥ iti yāvat
translated: Thus they are free from egoism and lack of discrimination, that is the meaning.

original: jitasaṅgadoṣāḥ priyāpriyasaṃvidhāv api rāgadveṣavarjitā iti yāvat /
analyzed: jita saṅga doṣāḥ priya apriya saṃvidhau api rāga dveṣa varjitāḥ iti yāvat
translated: They have conquered the fault of attachment, being free from attachment and aversion even in the arrangement of what is dear and what is not dear, that is the meaning.

original: adhyātmanityāḥ paramātmasvarūpalokcanatatparāḥ /🔽vinivṛttakāmā viśeṣeto niravaśeṣeṇa nivṛttāḥ kāmā viṣayabhogā yeṣāṃ te /
analyzed: adhyātma nityāḥ paramātma sva rūpa lokcana tatparāḥ  vinivṛtta kāmāḥ viśeṣa itas niravaśeṣeṇa nivṛttāḥ kāmāḥ viṣaya bhogāḥ yeṣām te
translated: They are always devoted to the Supreme Self, being intent on seeing its nature.🔽They are those in whom desire has turned away, who have turned away desire for objects of enjoyment in every way.

original: vivekavairāgyadvārā tyaktasarvakarmāṇa ity arthaḥ /
translated: The meaning is that they have given up all actions through discrimination and detachment.

original: dvandvaiḥ śītoṣṇādikṣutpipāsādibhiḥ sukhaduḥkhasaṃjñaiḥ sukhaduḥkhahetutvāt
analyzed: dvandvaiḥ śīta uṣṇa ādi kṣudh pipāsā ādibhiḥ sukha duḥkha saṃjñaiḥ sukha duḥkha hetu tvāt
translated: By the pairs of opposites, such as cold and heat, hunger and thirst, etc., which are called happiness and sorrow, because they are the causes of happiness and sorrow.

original: sukhaduḥkhanāmakaiḥ sukhaduḥkhasaṅgair iti pāṭhāntare sukhaduḥkhābhyāṃ saṅgaḥ
analyzed: sukha duḥkha nāmakaiḥ sukha duḥkha saṅgaiḥ iti pāṭha antare sukha duḥkhābhyām saṅgaḥ
translated: In another reading, by those attached to happiness and sorrow, means by those who are attached to happiness and sorrow.

original: sambandho yeṣāṃ taiḥ sukhaduḥkhasaṅgair
analyzed: sambandhaḥ yeṣām taiḥ sukha duḥkha saṅgaiḥ
translated: By those pairs of opposites which are attached to happiness and sorrow.

original: dvandvair vimuktāḥ parityaktāḥ /
analyzed: dvandvaiḥ vimuktāḥ parityaktāḥ
translated: They are liberated, i.e., abandoned, by the pairs of opposites.

original: amūḍhā vedāntapramāṇasaṃjātasamyagjñānanivāritātmaājñānās tad avyayaṃ yathoktaṃ padaṃ gacchanti ////
analyzed: amūḍhāḥ vedānta pramāṇa saṃjāta samyak jñāna nivārita ātma ājñānāḥ tat avyayam yathā uktam padam gacchanti
translated: They are not deluded, i.e., they have removed the ignorance of the self by means of the perfect knowledge produced by the Vedanta scriptures. They go to that imperishable state as described.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: tadbhaktau satyāṃ janāḥ kīdṛśā bhūtvā taṃ padaṃ prāpnuvantīty apekṣāyām āha nirmāneti /
analyzed: tad bhaktau satyām janāḥ kīdṛśāḥ bhūtvā tam padam prāpnuvanti iti apekṣāyām āha nirmāna iti
translated: When there is devotion to Him, what kind of people become and attain that state? Anticipating this, he says free from pride etc.
